content.description:
Dido learns of Aeneas’s plan

1 At regina dolos (quis fallere possit amantem?)

praesensit, motusque excepit prima futuros

omnia tuta timens. Eadem impia Fama furenti

detulit armari classem cursumque parari.

5 Saevit inops animi totamque incensa per urbem

bacchaturbacchor, bacchari, bacchatus sum: roam in a frenzy, qualis commotis excita sacris

ThyiasThyias, Thyiadis, f.: Bacchante, ubi audito stimulant trietericatrietericus, -a, -um: of alternate years Baccho

orgia nocturnusque vocat clamore CithaeronCithaeron, -onis, m.: mountain of Boeotia, sacred to Bacchus and the Muses.

Tandem his Aenean compellatcompello, -are: address reproachfully vocibus ultroultro: voluntarily, of one’s own accord:

10 “Dissimulare etiam sperastisperasti = speravisti, perfide, tantum

posse nefas tacitusque mea decedere terra?”
content.question: The word dolos (line 1) recalls the trick planned by which Greek hero?

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2

skill.text: 2.B: Describe historical and cultural contexts of Latin texts.
